nodes.title: Bootstrap TypeScript monorepo
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Bootstrap a typescript-based monorepo. Use npm. Create one package called spec. Two generator packages in a sub-dir called procedural and object. Two renderer packages in a sub-dir called svg and canvas. Bootstrap jest testing, eslint linting, prettier formatting and type checking. Append instructions to CLAUDE.md that describe success criteria for edits, and acceptance criteria before committing."}

nodes.title: Monorepo bootstrapped successfully
Committed monorepo bootstrap
Fix draft frame spec
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"feat/background-color","confidence":90,"prompt":"Let's fix the draft frame spec. Shape is not yet needed. We want Frame and it should be a type not an interface. It should specify only a background color. Renderers should render a 100x100 square of the color. The Generator interface has a single function `frame (time: number): Frame`. Renderer has `render(time: number): void`. It also have `loop(): void` and `stop(): void` to start and stop a render loop. Neither interfaces are generic. Implementations should default time to zero. renderers expect request animation frame support. renderers render a 100x100 square of the background color, and replace it if that is changed. Renderer constructors accept HTML elements of the relevant type."}

Create visual test app for renderer verification
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"feat/background-color","confidence":85,"prompt":"Create a test app so that we can visually confirm rendering is correct. It does not need to be a fully-fledged npm package, but it can be if that's best. Make it as simple as possible, with as few dependencies as possible. We want a page that displays the matrix of generator/renderer combinations. Each combination should render the same view, which for now is simply a background color. There should be an input field on the page to change the background color, all of the combinations should update when that happens. We need a way for claude code to run the app, inspect the page, and verify that the page is as expected. Examine the options for that, we can install any new claude code plugins if required."}

Integrate sub-agents into workflow
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"feat/circles","confidence":90,"prompt":"You are correct. First, though, we need to ensure that we have captured our inspriration for each generator correctly. One generator takes inspiration from p5.js where cilent code supplies a sketch that uses the generator API once per frame to specify what should be rendered. The other generator takes inspiration from three.js (and others) where client code constructs a scene graph of elements in the scene, then modifies it when the render should look different. I want to make sure we respect these considerations.

We can use sub-agents to look after each package. What do you think? There is an example from deciduous that I saw recently. The relevant fragment in the CLAUDE.md file is here (https://github.com/notactuallytreyanastasio/deciduous/blob/main/CLAUDE.md#subagents---domain-specific-context). It refers to an agents.toml file here (https://github.com/notactuallytreyanastasio/deciduous/blob/main/.claude/agents.toml). Tell me whether this is a suitable way to use sub-agents in claude code. If so, we should:
- Update the README files in each of our packages to capture the design considerations, constraints, inspiration and driver
- Write a agent spec for each package
- Update CLAUDE.md to INSIST that claude code uses the correct agent whenever we design changes for a package, make edits to the package, or review changes.

I will want you to propose the spec and instructions for each sub-agent. I may want to iterate, add or remove instructions - it will be easier for me if I can look at a proposal for each.

That's the next goal: integrating sub-agents into our workflow"}

nodes.title: Choose pattern for color properties in Frame spec
Stroke width not supported - using fixed 5 units/pixels
Implementing line rendering
Line rendering working - all 4 renderers produce identical output
File edits must use Task agents - updated CLAUDE.md with mandatory sub-agent workflow
Committed line rendering and sub-agent workflow
Frame spec is an IR - optimize for validation simplicity, not human readability. Generators provide ergonomic APIs, renderers pre-process as needed.
Flat: each shape has fill/stroke/strokeWidth properties directly. Simple but verbose, repetitive when shapes share styles.
Nested groups: shapes nested under style groups that provide fill/stroke. More compact for shared styles, but complex typedef, draw order requires careful nesting.
Global materials + references: Frame has materials table, shapes reference by ID. Like glTF. Compact but two structures (materials table + content tree).

Pure tree with ancestor references: single tree, root is complete material, all other materials are partial with required ref to ancestor. Shapes have no material properties. Validation is single-pass top-to-bottom.
Analogous systems: CSS (cascade + inheritance), USD (composition arcs), glTF (material references), SVG (defs + inheritance). Pure tree model closest to CSS cascading.
Groups not needed in pure tree model - Material nodes provide both style inheritance AND tree structure. Groups only needed later for transforms.

Ancestor-only references: prevents cycles by construction, enables single-pass validation, shared materials must be hoisted to common ancestor. Trade-off: sibling branches cannot share materials defined in one branch.
Pure tree model: RootMaterial has all properties required (fill, stroke, strokeWidth), no ref. ChildMaterial has all properties optional, ref required and must be ancestor ID, id required and unique.
Verbosity trade-off: single-shape overrides require wrapper Material node. Acceptable for IR - generators provide ergonomic APIs. Future optimization pass could compact frames.
Generator implications: p5.js push/pop maps to entering/exiting Material nodes. fill()/stroke() changes require new sibling Material branch. Generator must build tree, not flat list.
Tree structure: heterogeneous types vs generic node with payload
Heterogeneous types: Material/Transform have children, Shapes are leaves. Type-safe (shapes can't have children at compile time), but traversal needs per-type handling.
Generic node: all nodes have payload + optional children. Uniform traversal, but allows semantically invalid trees (circle with children). Must validate at runtime.
Selected heterogeneous types for now. Simpler, type-safe, sufficient for materials + shapes. Revisit when transforms land if pattern feels wrong.
Implement Material-based Frame spec with validation
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"feat/lines-color-and-fill","confidence":90,"prompt":"I think we should proceed. However, there are number of things we have talked about:
- implementing the new frame spec
- validating the frame spec - so we need to implement the first support for validation
- we will need to inject validation into the process! So far, we have said that renderers can assume frames are valid. But generators should not validate their own outputs. Perhaps for now we just put validation into the renderers.
- generators now have more work to do
- as do renderers

There is a lot of work there. We may need multiple sessions."}

{"branch":"feat/lines-color-and-fill","confidence":80,"prompt":"We are not yet finished! We implemented stroke and fill, but these are simply setting global properties that are inherited by all the shapes being rendered. We should follow TDD. We need to:

- update the test app to exercise a variety of different material properties, shapes and nesting"}

API vs IR confusion: Frame spec uses tree structure with Materials containing children. Object generator was designed to mirror IR structure instead of providing ergonomic three.js-style API. These should be decoupled - generator transforms natural API to IR.
Object generator API style: mirror IR tree vs three.js material references
IR mirroring (current): Materials contain children, shapes nested inside Materials
Three.js style (correct): Materials independent, shapes reference materials via property, generator builds IR tree

Add transform support to Frame spec
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"feat/transforms","confidence":90,"prompt":"I have some opinions. It would be good to have them challenged/validated.
- Opinion 1: Transform nodes are distinct in the Frame Spec, and sit in the tree in the same way that Materials do. There is no need to combine these two concerns.
- Opinion 2: There is no need for an "inheritance" mechanism as we had for materials. Every transform is complete and affects all of its children. Transforms **accumulate** when rendering, as a consumer of the generator APIs would expect.
- Opinion 3: translate, rotate and scale are generator API concerns. We do not **necessarily** need to reflect that in the Frame Spec, which is supposed to be an easy to validate and parse/traverse, machine-readable data structure. It should also be compact, where possible.

On opinion 3:
- this suggests that we could be maximally-explicit in the frame spec. Transform node is a matrix (affine transformation) that can capture any translation, rotation, scale or combination.
- that may, however, be verbose and inefficient from the perspective of size of the frame spec data structure. A translation can be expressed as metadata plus two numbers. But a matrix will require more data.
- perhaps for simple transformations, we can support more "compact" representations later - as an optimisation

Please dispatch task agents to examine different existing mechanisms. Three.js and p5.js are obvious choices, but there will be others so search for them first. Remember: our first task is to design the correct **intermediate representation** in the frame spec. For this, we need to capture the needs of a scene graph - so we may be driven by the needs of the renderers. It is **not** the same thing at the opinionated client APIs offered by generators."}

nodes.title: Choose transform representation for Frame IR
Matrix-only: 6-value 2D affine matrix [a,b,c,d,e,f]
TRS decomposed: separate translate, rotate, scale properties
Dual representation: TRS for API, matrix for IR (like three.js)
Operation stack: ordered list of operations (like USD xformOps)
Discriminated union: matrix OR compact forms (translate/rotate/scale)

Three.js: stores TRS properties (position, quaternion, scale) + computes matrix. matrixWorld = parentMatrixWorld  localMatrix. Uses 4x4 Matrix4 internally. Decomposition has known issues with non-uniform scale.

p5.js: immediate mode with matrix stack. 2D uses 6-element [a,b,c,d,e,f], WebGL uses 16-element 4x4. push()/pop() save/restore entire state including transforms. translate/rotate/scale multiply current matrix.

SVG: transform attribute supports both matrix(a,b,c,d,e,f) AND decomposed (translate, rotate, scale). Can mix freely. consolidate() merges to single matrix. Nested transforms accumulate via post-multiplication.
Canvas 2D: native 6-value affine matrix [a,b,c,d,e,f]. setTransform() replaces, transform() multiplies. save()/restore() manages state stack. getTransform() returns DOMMatrix snapshot.
glTF: allows TRS OR matrix (not both). TRS required for animation (can't interpolate arbitrary matrices). Composition order TRS. Matrix must be decomposable to TRS (no shear).
USD: operation stacks with explicit xformOpOrder. Most flexible - supports translate, rotate, scale, orient (quaternion), transform (matrix), shear. Enables non-destructive editing.
Lottie: decomposed properties only (anchor, position, scale, rotation). Animation-first design with keyframe support. Composition order implicit from After Effects.
RealityKit: TRS struct with SIMD types. Quaternion-only rotation. Entity-component architecture. Designed for runtime performance and animation interpolation.
VALIDATED: Transform accumulation (not inheritance) is universal. All systems use matrix multiplication: worldMatrix = parentWorld  localMatrix. No override mechanism like materials.
VALIDATED: Matrix as canonical form for render-focused IR. Both Canvas (6-value native) and SVG (matrix() attribute) consume matrices directly. TRS only needed if animation interpolation required.
NUANCED: Transform nodes distinct from Materials - validated for IR design, but most systems treat transform as node property not separate type. Renderers will extract matrix and apply to context.
2D affine matrix format: [a,b,c,d,e,f] representing |a c e| |b d f| |0 0 1|. Point (x,y) transforms to (ax+cy+e, bx+dy+f). Identity is [1,0,0,1,0,0].
Design decision: Transform node has NO id attribute (unlike Materials). Transforms don't need references - they just compose during traversal.
Design decision: Transforms and Materials nest flexibly and arbitrarily. Renderer's job to separate concerns during traversal (save/restore context appropriately).
Design decision: No compact identity representation. To express identity, simply omit the Transform node entirely.

Optimization strategy: Generators create output quickly without optimization. Post-processor can detect sequentially-nested transforms and combine into single matrix. Safe transformation - matrix multiplication is associative.
Selected: Matrix-only Transform nodes with 6-value 2D affine matrix. No id, flexible nesting with Materials, accumulate via multiplication. Compact forms deferred as future optimization.
